Title: IPv4NumToString(num)
Description: Takes a UInt32 number. Interprets it as an IPv4 address in big endian. Returns a string containing the corresponding IPv4 address in the format A.B.C.d (dot-separated numbers in decimal form).

Title: IPv4StringToNum(s)
Description: The reverse function of IPv4NumToString. If the IPv4 address has an invalid format, it throws exception.

Title: IPv4StringToNumOrDefault(s)
Description: Same as IPv4StringToNum, but if the IPv4 address has an invalid format, it returns 0.

Title: IPv4StringToNumOrNull(s)
Description: Same as IPv4StringToNum, but if the IPv4 address has an invalid format, it returns null.

Title: IPv4NumToStringClassC(num)
Description: Similar to IPv4NumToString, but using xxx instead of the last octet.
Examples: SELECT    IPv4NumToStringClassC(ClientIP) AS k,    count() AS cFROM test.hitsGROUP BY kORDER BY c DESCLIMIT 10
SELECT    IPv6NumToString(ClientIP6 AS k),    count() AS cFROM hits_allWHERE EventDate = today() AND substring(ClientIP6, 1, 12) != unhex('00000000000000000000FFFF')GROUP BY kORDER BY c DESCLIMIT 10
SELECT    IPv6NumToString(ClientIP6 AS k),    count() AS cFROM hits_allWHERE EventDate = today()GROUP BY kORDER BY c DESCLIMIT 10

Title: IPv6StringToNum
Description: The reverse function of IPv6NumToString. If the IPv6 address has an invalid format, it throws exception.

If the input string contains a valid IPv4 address, returns its IPv6 equivalent.
HEX can be uppercase or lowercase.
IPv6 address in binary format. FixedString(16).
Examples: SELECT addr, cutIPv6(IPv6StringToNum(addr), 0, 0) FROM (SELECT ['notaddress', '127.0.0.1', '1111::ffff'] AS addr) ARRAY JOIN addr;

Title: IPv6StringToNumOrDefault(s)
Description: Same as IPv6StringToNum, but if the IPv6 address has an invalid format, it returns 0.

Title: IPv6StringToNumOrNull(s)
Description: Same as IPv6StringToNum, but if the IPv6 address has an invalid format, it returns null.

Title: IPv4ToIPv6(x)
Description: Takes a UInt32 number. Interprets it as an IPv4 address in big endian. Returns a FixedString(16) value containing the IPv6 address in binary format. Examples:

Title: cutIPv6(x, bytesToCutForIPv6, bytesToCutForIPv4)
Description: Accepts a FixedString(16) value containing the IPv6 address in binary format. Returns a string containing the address of the specified number of bytes removed in text format. For example:
WITH    IPv6StringToNum('2001:0DB8:AC10:FE01:FEED:BABE:CAFE:F00D') AS ipv6,    IPv4ToIPv6(IPv4StringToNum('192.168.0.1')) AS ipv4SELECT    cutIPv6(ipv6, 2, 0),    cutIPv6(ipv4, 0, 2)
Examples: WITH    IPv6StringToNum('2001:0DB8:AC10:FE01:FEED:BABE:CAFE:F00D') AS ipv6,    IPv4ToIPv6(IPv4StringToNum('192.168.0.1')) AS ipv4SELECT    cutIPv6(ipv6, 2, 0),    cutIPv6(ipv4, 0, 2)

Title: IPv4CIDRToRange(ipv4, Cidr),
Description: Accepts an IPv4 and an UInt8 value containing the CIDR. Return a tuple with two IPv4 containing the lower range and the higher range of the subnet.

Title: IPv6CIDRToRange(ipv6, Cidr),
Description: Accepts an IPv6 and an UInt8 value containing the CIDR. Return a tuple with two IPv6 containing the lower range and the higher range of the subnet.

Title: toIPv4
Description: Like IPv4StringToNum but takes a string form of IPv4 address and returns value of IPv4 type.
string converted to the IPv4 address. IPv4.

Title: toIPv4OrDefault
Description: Same as toIPv4, but if the IPv4 address has an invalid format, it returns 0.0.0.0 (0 IPv4), or the provided IPv4 default.
value — IP address. String.default (optional) — The value to return if string has an invalid format. IPv4.
string converted to the current IPv4 address. String.
Examples: WITH    '::ffff:127.0.0.1' AS valid_IPv6_string,    'fe80:2030:31:24' AS invalid_IPv6_stringSELECT    toIPv4OrDefault(valid_IPv6_string) AS valid,    toIPv4OrDefault(invalid_IPv6_string) AS default,    toIPv4OrDefault(invalid_IPv6_string, toIPv4('1.1.1.1')) AS provided_default;

Title: toIPv4OrNull
Description: Same as toIPv4, but if the IPv4 address has an invalid format, it returns null.
string converted to the current IPv4 address, or null if string is an invalid address. String.

Title: toIPv4OrZero
Description: Same as toIPv4, but if the IPv4 address has an invalid format, it returns 0.0.0.0.
string converted to the current IPv4 address, or 0.0.0.0 if string is an invalid address. String.
Examples: WITH 'Not an IP address' AS invalid_IPv6_stringSELECT toIPv4OrZero(invalid_IPv6_string);

Title: toIPv6
Description:
Converts a string form of IPv6 address to IPv6 type. If the IPv6 address has an invalid format, returns an empty value.
Similar to IPv6StringToNum function, which converts IPv6 address to binary format.
If the input string contains a valid IPv4 address, then the IPv6 equivalent of the IPv4 address is returned.

Title: toIPv6OrDefault
Description: Same as toIPv6, but if the IPv6 address has an invalid format, it returns :: (0 IPv6) or the provided IPv6 default.
string — IP address. String.default (optional) — The value to return if string has an invalid format. IPv6.
IPv6 address IPv6, otherwise :: or the provided optional default if string has an invalid format.
Examples: WITH    '127.0.0.1' AS valid_IPv4_string,    '127.0.0.1.6' AS invalid_IPv4_stringSELECT    toIPv6OrDefault(valid_IPv4_string) AS valid,    toIPv6OrDefault(invalid_IPv4_string) AS default,    toIPv6OrDefault(invalid_IPv4_string, toIPv6('1.1.1.1')) AS provided_default

Title: toIPv6OrNull
Description: Same as toIPv6, but if the IPv6 address has an invalid format, it returns null.
IP address. IPv6, or null if string is not a valid format.

Title: toIPv6OrZero
Description: Same as toIPv6, but if the IPv6 address has an invalid format, it returns ::.
IP address. IPv6, or :: if string is not a valid format.

Title: IPv6StringToNumOrDefault(s)
Description: Same as toIPv6, but if the IPv6 address has an invalid format, it returns 0.

Title: IPv6StringToNumOrNull(s)
Description: Same as toIPv6, but if the IPv6 address has an invalid format, it returns null.

Title: isIPv4String
Description: Determines whether the input string is an IPv4 address or not. If string is IPv6 address returns 0.
1 if string is IPv4 address, 0 otherwise. UInt8.
Examples: SELECT addr, isIPv4String(addr) FROM ( SELECT ['0.0.0.0', '127.0.0.1', '::ffff:127.0.0.1'] AS addr ) ARRAY JOIN addr;

Title: isIPv6String
Description: Determines whether the input string is an IPv6 address or not. If string is IPv4 address returns 0.
1 if string is IPv6 address, 0 otherwise. UInt8.
Examples: SELECT addr, isIPv6String(addr) FROM ( SELECT ['::', '1111::ffff', '::ffff:127.0.0.1', '127.0.0.1'] AS addr ) ARRAY JOIN addr;

Title: isIPAddressInRange
Description: Determines if an IP address is contained in a network represented in the CIDR notation. Returns 1 if true, or 0 otherwise.
This function accepts both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses (and networks) represented as strings. It returns 0 if the IP version of the address and the CIDR don't match.
address — An IPv4 or IPv6 address. String.prefix — An IPv4 or IPv6 network prefix in CIDR. String.
